title: Contextual Applications of Differentiation
description: Students apply derivatives to real-world and mathematical contexts. Topics include related rates (translating verbal scenarios into equations and differentiating implicitly with respect to time), straight-line motion (connecting position, velocity, and acceleration), local linearization and differentials (using the tangent line to approximate function values), and L'Hopital's Rule (resolving indeterminate forms). AP weight 10-15%. Weekly rhythm includes FRQ-style contextual differentiation problems.
goals: Set up and solve related rates problems by identifying variables, writing geometric or physical equations, differentiating implicitly with respect to time, and substituting known values.

Interpret straight-line motion using derivatives: velocity as the derivative of position, acceleration as the derivative of velocity, speed as absolute value of velocity, and determine when an object changes direction or speeds up/slows down.
Use local linearization L(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x - a) and differentials dy = f'(x)dx to approximate function values, and determine whether approximations overestimate or underestimate from concavity.
Apply L'Hopital's Rule to evaluate limits in 0/0 and infinity/infinity indeterminate forms, including cases requiring multiple applications.
instructionalStrategy: Gradual release: concept-intro -> I Do -> concept-check -> We Do -> check-in -> You Do -> mastery-check
AI uses scaffold array as scope and worked-example bank; AI makes all instructional decisions
Related rates: emphasize the 5-step setup process (draw, label, equation, differentiate, substitute) before any computation
Motion: build intuition with number-line animations before formal sign-analysis of velocity and acceleration
Spiral prior: implicit differentiation from Unit 3 and chain rule fluency are prerequisites

scaffold.title: Related Rates: Setup & Strategy
scaffold.content: Related rates problems ask: given how fast one quantity changes, how fast does a related quantity change? The key insight is that every variable is a function of time t, so differentiating any equation connecting them produces a relationship among their rates. The setup is everything — most errors come from skipping steps, not from calculus mistakes.
keyPoints: Step 1 — Draw a picture. Label ALL relevant quantities with variables. Do NOT label anything with a number if it changes over time.
Step 2 — Identify what you KNOW (given rates: dx/dt, dy/dt, etc.) and what you WANT (the unknown rate).
Step 3 — Write an equation relating the variables. Use geometry (Pythagorean theorem, similar triangles, area/volume formulas, trig) — NOT rates yet.
Step 4 — Differentiate both sides with respect to t using implicit differentiation and the chain rule. Every variable gets a d/dt.
Step 5 — Substitute all known values (including the specific moment's measurements and rates) and solve for the unknown rate.

Classic scenarios: ladder sliding down a wall (Pythagorean), expanding/draining cone (volume), balloon inflating (sphere volume/surface area), shadow lengthening (similar triangles), two objects moving (distance formula).
Common trap: substituting specific values BEFORE differentiating. Always differentiate the general equation first.

examples.problem: A 10-ft ladder leans against a vertical wall. The bottom slides away from the wall at 2 ft/s. How fast is the top sliding down when the bottom is 6 ft from the wall?
examples.solution: Draw: right triangle with wall (y), ground (x), ladder (10). Given: dx/dt = 2 ft/s. Want: dy/dt when x = 6. Equation: x² + y² = 100. When x = 6: 36 + y² = 100, so y = 8. Differentiate: 2x(dx/dt) + 2y(dy/dt) = 0. Substitute: 2(6)(2) + 2(8)(dy/dt) = 0. 24 + 16(dy/dt) = 0. dy/dt = -24/16 = -3/2 ft/s. The top slides down at 3/2 ft/s (negative because y is decreasing).

examples.problem: A spherical balloon is inflated so that its volume increases at a constant rate of 10 cubic cm per second. How fast is the radius increasing when the radius is 5 cm?
examples.solution: Draw: sphere with radius r. Given: dV/dt = 10 cm³/s. Want: dr/dt when r = 5. Equation: V = (4/3)pi r³. Differentiate: dV/dt = 4pi r²(dr/dt). Substitute: 10 = 4pi(25)(dr/dt). dr/dt = 10/(100pi) = 1/(10pi) cm/s, approximately 0.0318 cm/s.

examples.problem: Water drains from a conical tank (height 12 ft, radius 4 ft at top) at 3 ft³/min. How fast is the water level dropping when the water is 6 ft deep?
examples.solution: Draw: inverted cone. By similar triangles: r/h = 4/12 = 1/3, so r = h/3. Volume: V = (1/3)pi r²h = (1/3)pi(h/3)²h = pi h³/27. Given: dV/dt = -3 ft³/min (draining, so negative). Want: dh/dt when h = 6. Differentiate: dV/dt = (pi/27)(3h²)(dh/dt) = (pi h²/9)(dh/dt). Substitute: -3 = (pi(36)/9)(dh/dt) = 4pi(dh/dt). dh/dt = -3/(4pi) ft/min, approximately -0.239 ft/min. The water level drops at 3/(4pi) ft/min.

scaffold.title: Motion Along a Line: Position, Velocity & Acceleration
scaffold.content: When an object moves along a straight line, its position function s(t) encodes everything about its motion. The first derivative gives velocity (rate of position change), the second gives acceleration (rate of velocity change). Sign analysis reveals direction, speed changes, and turning points.
keyPoints: Velocity: v(t) = s'(t). Positive means moving right/up; negative means moving left/down.
Acceleration: a(t) = v'(t) = s''(t). Positive means velocity is increasing; negative means velocity is decreasing.
Speed: |v(t)|. Speed is always non-negative. Speed is the magnitude of velocity, not the same as velocity.
Object changes direction when v(t) changes sign (v = 0 and sign changes). Check a sign chart of v(t).
Speeding up: v(t) and a(t) have the SAME sign (both positive or both negative). The velocity is moving further from zero.
Slowing down: v(t) and a(t) have OPPOSITE signs. The velocity is moving toward zero.
Object is at rest when v(t) = 0. Being at rest does not necessarily mean direction changes — v could touch zero and bounce back.
Displacement over [a, b]: s(b) - s(a). Total distance over [a, b]: integral of |v(t)| dt (not tested in this unit, but conceptually important).

scaffold.title: Motion Along a Line — Worked Examples

examples.problem: A particle moves along the x-axis with position s(t) = t³ - 6t² + 9t + 2 for t >= 0. Find when the particle is at rest, moving left, and moving right. When does it change direction?
examples.solution: v(t) = s'(t) = 3t² - 12t + 9 = 3(t² - 4t + 3) = 3(t - 1)(t - 3). v(t) = 0 at t = 1 and t = 3 (at rest). Sign chart: v(t) > 0 on (0, 1) — moving right. v(t) < 0 on (1, 3) — moving left. v(t) > 0 on (3, infinity) — moving right. Direction changes at t = 1 (right to left) and t = 3 (left to right) because v changes sign at both.

examples.problem: Using the same position function s(t) = t³ - 6t² + 9t + 2, determine when the particle is speeding up and slowing down.
examples.solution: v(t) = 3(t - 1)(t - 3). a(t) = v'(t) = 6t - 12 = 6(t - 2). a(t) = 0 at t = 2. Sign analysis: on (0, 1), v > 0 and a < 0 — opposite signs — slowing down. On (1, 2), v < 0 and a < 0 — same sign — speeding up. On (2, 3), v < 0 and a > 0 — opposite signs — slowing down. On (3, infinity), v > 0 and a > 0 — same sign — speeding up.

examples.problem: A particle has velocity v(t) = sin(t) - cos(t) for 0 <= t <= 2pi. Find the acceleration at t = pi/4. Is the particle speeding up or slowing down at t = pi/4?
examples.solution: a(t) = v'(t) = cos(t) + sin(t). At t = pi/4: a(pi/4) = cos(pi/4) + sin(pi/4) = sqrt(2)/2 + sqrt(2)/2 = sqrt(2). Now check v(pi/4) = sin(pi/4) - cos(pi/4) = sqrt(2)/2 - sqrt(2)/2 = 0. Since v(pi/4) = 0, the particle is instantaneously at rest — it is neither speeding up nor slowing down at this exact moment. (Speed is |v| = 0 and is about to increase.)

problems.problem: A 6-ft tall man walks away from a 15-ft streetlight at 4 ft/s. How fast is the tip of his shadow moving along the ground when he is 20 ft from the light?
hints: Draw the picture: streetlight, man, and shadow form similar triangles
Let x = distance of man from light, s = length of shadow. By similar triangles: 15/(x + s) = 6/s
Cross-multiply: 15s = 6x + 6s, so 9s = 6x, giving s = (2/3)x
The tip of the shadow is at distance x + s from the light. Differentiate x + s with respect to t.
problems.answer: s = (2/3)x, so the tip is at x + s = x + (2/3)x = (5/3)x. d(tip)/dt = (5/3)(dx/dt) = (5/3)(4) = 20/3 ft/s. The shadow tip moves at 20/3 ft/s regardless of the man's distance from the light.

problems.problem: Two cars leave an intersection at the same time. Car A heads east at 30 mph and Car B heads north at 40 mph. How fast is the distance between them increasing after 2 hours?
hints: Draw: right triangle. a = distance east, b = distance north, d = distance between them
a² + b² = d². At t = 2: a = 60, b = 80, so d = 100
da/dt = 30, db/dt = 40. Differentiate: 2a(da/dt) + 2b(db/dt) = 2d(dd/dt)

problems.problem: A particle moves along the x-axis with position s(t) = te^(-t) for t >= 0. Find the velocity and acceleration at t = 1. Is the particle speeding up or slowing down at t = 1?
hints: v(t) = s'(t) using the product rule: (1)e^(-t) + t(-e^(-t)) = e^(-t)(1 - t)
a(t) = v'(t) using the product rule on e^(-t)(1 - t)
Evaluate v(1) and a(1), then check if their signs agree or disagree
problems.answer: v(t) = e^(-t)(1 - t). v(1) = e^(-1)(0) = 0. The particle is at rest at t = 1. a(t) = -e^(-t)(1 - t) + e^(-t)(-1) = e^(-t)(t - 2). a(1) = e^(-1)(-1) = -1/e < 0. Since v(1) = 0, the particle is instantaneously at rest. Checking nearby: v changes from positive (t < 1) to negative (t > 1), so t = 1 is a direction change.

problems.problem: The radius of an oil spill (circular) is growing at 3 m/min. At what rate is the area increasing when the radius is 20 m?
hints: A = pi r²
Differentiate: dA/dt = 2pi r (dr/dt)
Substitute r = 20 and dr/dt = 3

scaffold.title: Local Linearization & Differentials
scaffold.content: The tangent line at a point is the best linear approximation to the curve near that point. Local linearization uses this idea to approximate function values that are hard to compute exactly. Differentials give a compact notation for estimating how much a function changes.
keyPoints: Linearization: L(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x - a). This is the tangent line at x = a used as an approximation for f(x) when x is near a.
Choose a so that f(a) and f'(a) are easy to compute (nice numbers), and x is close to a.
Differential notation: dy = f'(x) dx. Here dx is a small change in x, and dy approximates the resulting change in y.
Relationship: delta y (actual change) approximately equals dy (estimated change). The approximation improves as dx shrinks.

Over/underestimate: if f is concave up (f'' > 0) near a, the tangent line lies BELOW the curve — linearization UNDERESTIMATES. If f is concave down (f'' < 0), the tangent line lies ABOVE — linearization OVERESTIMATES.
AP FRQ tip: when asked whether an approximation is an over- or underestimate, cite concavity as your justification.

examples.solution: Let f(x) = sqrt(x). Choose a = 4 (perfect square, close to 4.1). f(4) = 2. f'(x) = 1/(2sqrt(x)), so f'(4) = 1/4. L(x) = 2 + (1/4)(x - 4). L(4.1) = 2 + (1/4)(0.1) = 2 + 0.025 = 2.025. Actual: sqrt(4.1) = 2.02485... The linearization slightly overestimates. Why? f''(x) = -1/(4x^(3/2)) < 0, so f is concave down — tangent line is above the curve.

examples.problem: The side of a cube is measured as 5 cm with a possible error of +/- 0.02 cm. Use differentials to estimate the maximum error in the calculated volume.
examples.solution: V = s³. dV = 3s² ds. With s = 5 and ds = +/- 0.02: dV = 3(25)(+/- 0.02) = +/- 1.5 cm³. The volume is approximately 125 +/- 1.5 cm³. The relative error is |dV/V| = 1.5/125 = 0.012 = 1.2%.

examples.problem: Given f(3) = 7 and f'(3) = -2, approximate f(3.05) using linearization. If f''(3) > 0, is this an overestimate or underestimate?
examples.solution: L(x) = f(3) + f'(3)(x - 3) = 7 + (-2)(x - 3). L(3.05) = 7 + (-2)(0.05) = 7 - 0.1 = 6.9. Since f''(3) > 0, the function is concave up near x = 3. A concave-up function curves above its tangent line, so the tangent line (our linearization) lies below the actual curve. Therefore 6.9 is an UNDERESTIMATE of f(3.05).

scaffold.title: L'Hopital's Rule
scaffold.content: L'Hopital's Rule is a powerful technique for evaluating limits that produce indeterminate forms. When direct substitution gives 0/0 or infinity/infinity, you can differentiate the numerator and denominator SEPARATELY (not using the quotient rule) and try the limit again.
keyPoints: Applies ONLY to indeterminate forms: 0/0 or infinity/infinity. Always verify the form first.
The rule: if lim(x->c) f(x)/g(x) gives 0/0 or inf/inf, then lim(x->c) f(x)/g(x) = lim(x->c) f'(x)/g'(x), provided the latter limit exists.
Differentiate numerator and denominator SEPARATELY. This is NOT the quotient rule — you take f'(x) and g'(x) independently.
You may need to apply L'Hopital's Rule more than once if the result is still indeterminate. Re-check the form each time.
Other indeterminate forms (0 * infinity, infinity - infinity, 0^0, 1^infinity, infinity^0) must be algebraically rewritten as 0/0 or infinity/infinity before applying L'Hopital's.
Common trap: applying L'Hopital's when the form is NOT indeterminate (e.g., 5/0 or 3/7). The rule does not apply in those cases.
When L'Hopital's applies, the derivatives should simplify the expression. If it gets more complicated, consider an alternative algebraic approach.

examples.problem: Evaluate: lim(x->0) sin(x)/x using L'Hopital's Rule.
examples.solution: Check form: sin(0)/0 = 0/0. Indeterminate — L'Hopital's applies. Differentiate separately: d/dx[sin(x)] = cos(x), d/dx[x] = 1. lim(x->0) cos(x)/1 = cos(0) = 1. This confirms the well-known result: lim(x->0) sin(x)/x = 1.

Check form: infinity/infinity. L'Hopital's applies. First application: lim(x->infinity) (6x + 2)/(e^x). Still infinity/infinity. Second application: lim(x->infinity) 6/(e^x) = 6/infinity = 0. Exponential growth dominates polynomial growth. The limit is 0.

Check form: (1 - 1 - 0)/0 = 0/0. L'Hopital's applies. First application: lim(x->0) (e^x - 1)/(2x). Check: (1 - 1)/0 = 0/0. Still indeterminate. Second application: lim(x->0) e^x/2 = 1/2. The limit is 1/2.

problems.problem: Use linearization to approximate (1.02)^5. Is this an overestimate or underestimate?
hints: Let f(x) = x^5 with a = 1 (nice base point near 1.02)
L(1.02) = 1 + 5(0.02). Then check f''(x) = 20x^3 > 0 for concavity.
problems.answer: L(1.02) = 1 + 5(0.02) = 1.10. Since f''(x) = 20x^3 > 0 (concave up) near x = 1, the tangent line is below the curve, so 1.10 is an UNDERESTIMATE. Actual: (1.02)^5 = 1.10408...

hints: Check: (0 - 0)/0 = 0/0. L'Hopital's applies.
First application: (sec²(x) - 1)/(3x²). Check form again: 0/0.
Second application: differentiate numerator (2sec²(x)tan(x)) and denominator (6x). Still 0/0.
Third application: differentiate again and evaluate at x = 0.
problems.answer: First: lim (sec²x - 1)/(3x²) = 0/0. Note: sec²x - 1 = tan²x, so lim tan²x/(3x²) = (1/3) lim (tanx/x)² = (1/3)(1)² = 1/3. Alternatively, continue L'Hopital's: second application gives lim 2sec²x tanx/(6x) = 0/0. Third application: lim (2sec^4x + 4sec²x tan²x·... )/6. Evaluating carefully at x = 0 yields 2/6 = 1/3.

hints: This is an infinity * 0 form. Rewrite as: ln(1 + 3/x)/(1/x)
Now it is 0/0 as x -> infinity (since 1/x -> 0). Apply L'Hopital's.
Differentiate numerator and denominator with respect to x.
problems.answer: Rewrite: lim ln(1 + 3/x)/(1/x). Form: 0/0. Differentiate: numerator derivative = [1/(1 + 3/x)](-3/x²) = -3/(x²(1 + 3/x)). Denominator derivative = -1/x². Ratio: [-3/(x²(1 + 3/x))]/(-1/x²) = 3/(1 + 3/x). As x -> infinity: 3/(1 + 0) = 3.

scaffold.title: Contextual Applications of Differentiation — Mastery Practice

problems.problem: A boat is pulled toward a dock by a rope attached to the bow. The rope is wound through a pulley on the dock that is 6 ft higher than the bow. If the rope is pulled in at 2 ft/s, how fast is the boat approaching the dock when 10 ft of rope is out?
problems.answer: Let r = rope length, x = horizontal distance. r² = x² + 36. When r = 10: x² = 100 - 36 = 64, so x = 8. Differentiate: 2r(dr/dt) = 2x(dx/dt). 2(10)(-2) = 2(8)(dx/dt). -40 = 16(dx/dt). dx/dt = -5/2 ft/s. The boat approaches at 5/2 ft/s.

problems.problem: A particle moves along the x-axis with velocity v(t) = 3t² - 12t + 9. Find all times when the particle changes direction. Determine when the particle is speeding up on the interval [0, 5].
problems.answer: v(t) = 3(t - 1)(t - 3) = 0 at t = 1 and t = 3. Sign of v: positive on (0,1), negative on (1,3), positive on (3,5). Direction changes at t = 1 and t = 3. a(t) = 6t - 12 = 0 at t = 2. Sign of a: negative on (0,2), positive on (2,5). Speeding up when v and a share sign: on (1,2) both negative (speeding up), on (3,5) both positive (speeding up). Speeding up on (1, 2) union (3, 5).

problems.problem: Use the tangent line to f(x) = ln(x) at x = 1 to approximate ln(1.05). Is this an overestimate or underestimate? Justify with concavity.
problems.answer: f(1) = 0. f'(x) = 1/x, f'(1) = 1. L(x) = 0 + 1(x - 1) = x - 1. L(1.05) = 0.05. Actual ln(1.05) = 0.04879... Since f''(x) = -1/x² < 0, f is concave down. The tangent line lies above the curve, so 0.05 is an OVERESTIMATE.

problems.problem: An inverted conical tank has height 10 m and top radius 5 m. Water flows in at 2 m³/min and leaks out at 0.5 m³/min. How fast is the water level rising when the depth is 4 m?
problems.answer: Net flow: dV/dt = 2 - 0.5 = 1.5 m³/min. Similar triangles: r/h = 5/10 = 1/2, so r = h/2. V = (1/3)pi r²h = (1/3)pi(h/2)²h = pi h³/12. Differentiate: dV/dt = (pi/12)(3h²)(dh/dt) = (pi h²/4)(dh/dt). At h = 4: 1.5 = (16pi/4)(dh/dt) = 4pi(dh/dt). dh/dt = 1.5/(4pi) = 3/(8pi) m/min, approximately 0.119 m/min.

problems.problem: A particle moves along a line with position s(t) = t³ - 9t² + 24t for t >= 0. (a) Find the total number of times the particle changes direction. (b) Find the particle's position at each direction change. (c) At t = 3, is the particle speeding up or slowing down?
problems.answer: (a) v(t) = 3t² - 18t + 24 = 3(t² - 6t + 8) = 3(t - 2)(t - 4) = 0 at t = 2, t = 4. v changes sign at both, so 2 direction changes. (b) s(2) = 8 - 36 + 48 = 20. s(4) = 64 - 144 + 96 = 16. (c) v(3) = 27 - 54 + 24 = -3 < 0. a(t) = 6t - 18. a(3) = 0. Since a(3) = 0, the particle is neither speeding up nor slowing down at that instant (acceleration is zero).

answerKeys.rr-ladder: dy/dt = -3/2 ft/s. Top slides down at 3/2 ft/s.
answerKeys.motion-cubic-direction: At rest t=1,3. Right (0,1)+(3,inf). Left (1,3). Changes direction t=1,3.
answerKeys.motion-trig-v0: v(pi/4)=0, a(pi/4)=sqrt(2). At rest; neither speeding up nor slowing down.
answerKeys.wp-motion-exponential: v(1)=0, a(1)=-1/e. At rest, direction change at t=1.
answerKeys.ip-rr-boat: dx/dt = -5/2 ft/s. Boat approaches at 5/2 ft/s.
answerKeys.ip-motion-full: 2 direction changes at t=2,4. s(2)=20, s(4)=16. At t=3: a=0, neither speeding up nor slowing down.
